poem:
Cancer's Conundrum

Between the pages of loss  
and discovery's relentless chase—  
a mother, a son, and a million cries,  
threaded through a needle's eye.  
In labs of sterile light, hope whispers  
and shrouded cells expose their  
reluctant secrets—each breakthrough,  
a soft murmur against  
inevitable silence.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "British professor makes ‘thrilling’ breakthrough for cancer that killed his mother Professor Paul Workman was 37 and already well established as a medical researcher when his mother, Ena, died of a rare bone cancer known as chordoma. About one in a million people are affected by the condition, which is untreatable. “It was utterly frustrating,” said Workman, who later became head of the Centre for Cancer Drug Discovery and then chief executive of the Institute". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
